text: Midday light leaked through gaps in the clouds, falling across the inn’s sign as dust motes spun in the beam. The hearth was still lit, the air carrying the smell of bread and stew.
I had just finished mopping the floor, the bandage at the corner of my mouth still pulling painfully, when the doorbell chimed softly.
A girl with chestnut hair tied into a short braid pushed the door open. She carried a basket full of medicine bottles, each a different color, like dew trapped by sunlight.
"Excuse me… sorry to bother you! Does a lady named Alicia happen to be staying here?"
"…She is." I touched my bandage. "Why?"
Her gaze immediately fell on the bruise on my face. She stiffened noticeably.
"You’re hurt?! Did—did someone cause trouble?"
"A drunk. He’s already gone."
"Again…" She bit the word back mid-sentence, realizing she’d slipped, then quickly corrected herself. "I mean—why are people like that always the same?!"
She set the basket down on the counter, moving quickly but carefully, like she was afraid of hurting me.
"My name is Lucia. I’m her apprentice. She was already in a bad state before leaving this morning… I followed her all the way here."
"She’s upstairs."
No sooner had I said it than soft footsteps sounded outside—unhurried, unforced, like arrival itself was a burden.
Alicia stepped inside. Frost still clung to her silver-white cloak, and a bit of mud stained the edge of her armor. Her gaze was flat—so flat it felt like every emotion had been sealed away.
"Mentor!"
Lucia almost rushed forward, but stopped herself two steps away, as if afraid she might shatter her by getting too close.
"Don’t shout."
"I can hear you."
She pulled her cloak back over her shoulders, her gaze passing over the injury on my face without a flicker of expression—like she’d seen the same scene far too many times.
"You already looked terrible this morning! I said I’d come with you, but you wouldn’t let me… did you do it again—"
"Lucia." She cut her off. Her voice wasn’t loud, but it severed the sentence like a dull blade. "Not here."
Lucia swallowed the rest of her words, her eyes reddening instantly.
"…Then at least sit down. Your hands are shaking."
"I’m fine."
"You always say that!"
Her voice was full of worry, even edged with frustration—the kind only someone close would dare to show.
"Lucia… maybe have something warm first? I’ve got soup."
"Yes! Thank you!"
She immediately turned back to rummage through the medicine basket, like she’d finally found something she could do.
"Sir, this wound needs disinfecting. I have some herbal salve here… and pain relief too."
"…You don’t have to go to all that trouble."
"It’s not trouble! You were beaten because of her, right?"
As soon as she said it, she looked at Alicia, like she was afraid of provoking her.
"Don’t drag me into it."
"He got hit because he was unlucky."
She said it coldly, like she was cutting responsibility clean away. But inside her sleeve, her fingers tightened slightly—a tiny motion, like she was holding something back.
"Mentor… don’t be like that."
"This is how I am."
She walked to the notice board behind the counter, her eyes briefly checking the placement of the room keys, like she was confirming something she already knew.
"Two rooms."
"…Together?"
"No."
"One for her. One for me."
Lucia froze for a moment, clearly wanting to object, but held herself back. She clutched the medicine basket, like she was turning herself into a cushion, ready to catch her if she fell apart.
"Th-then I’ll take the room next to yours! That way, if you feel unwell at night, I’ll hear it."
"Do what you want."
Alicia’s answer was cold, but not a refusal—as if even refusing took too much effort.
"Sir, I’ll treat your wound first. Please don’t move."
She applied the salve to the split at the corner of my mouth, her movements so careful it felt like she was touching porcelain.
"…Don’t use that one."
"Why?"
"It heals too fast."
She said it like common knowledge. Lucia froze, her expression turning even more unsettled—like she’d heard experience that shouldn’t exist.
"…Th-then I’ll switch to a normal one."
Alicia said nothing more. She draped her cloak over the back of a chair and sat down. In that instant, it felt like she finally let out a breath—or like she might fall asleep and never wake up.
The brass die lay quietly on the counter. Lucia busied herself taking care of me, while Alicia seemed completely detached from the warmth around her.
Her coldness wasn’t arrogance—it was more like she’d locked herself inside a shell. Because the moment she opened it, she would fall apart.

options.text: Option A: Ask Alicia directly in front of Lucia, “What’s wrong with you today?” 【Charisma Check (DC 6)】
Option B: Look for a chance to ask her in private 【No Check (DC 0)】
